review.title: On learning to localize objects with minimal supervision
review.abstract: Learning to localize objects with minimal supervision is an important problem in computer vision, since large fully annotated datasets are extremely costly to obtain. In this paper, we propose a new method that achieves this goal with only image-level labels of whether the objects are present or not. Our approach combines a discriminative submodular cover problem for automatically discovering a set of positive object windows with a smoothed latent SVM formulation. The latter allows us to leverage efficient Quasi-Newton optimization techniques. Our experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach provides approximately 70% relative improvement in average precision over the current state of the art on standard benchmark datasets.

metadata.title: On learning to localize objects with minimal supervision

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The classic paradigm for learning object recognition begins with the annotation of each object instance, in all educational images, with a delimitation box. However, this exhaustive labeling approach is costly and error prone to large-scale datasets. The vast amount of textually annotated visual data available online inspires another, more difficult research problem. Can weakly labeled images without delimitation boxes be used to reliably train object detectors? In this alternative paradigm, the goal is to learn to locate objects with minimal surveillance (Weber et al., 2000a; b). We focus on the case where the student has access to binary image labels that encode whether an image contains the target object or not, without access to instance-level annotations (i.e., delimitation boxes). Our approach begins by reducing the number of possible detection processes at the 31st International Conference on Machine Learning, Beijing, 2014, China.

sections.heading: 2. Related work
sections.text: Our work relates to three active areas of research: (1) weakly supervised learning, (2) unattended discovery of medium-level visual elements, and (3) co-segmentation, building on a number of earlier approaches to the formation of object detectors from poorly labeled data; in almost all cases, the task is formulated as a multiple instance (MIL) problem (Long & Tan, 1996), in which the learner has access to an image-level label indicating the presence or absence of the target class, but not its location (if it exists); the challenge facing the learner is to find the signal fragments present in the positive images, but not in the negative images; the implicit assumption is that this signal corresponds to the positive class; although there has been recent work on convex relations (Li et al., 2013; Joulin & Bach, 2012), most MIL algorithms are initiation algorithms.

sections.heading: 3. Problem formulation
sections.text: Our goal is to learn a detector for a visual category from a set of images, each with a binary label. However, we model an image as a series of overlapping rectangular windows and follow a standard approach to detection: reduce the detection problem to the problem of binary classification of image windows. However, at training time, we only receive image captions at image level, which results in classic multiple instance learning (MIL). We can consider each image as a "bag" of instances (rectangular windows), and the binary image caption y = 1 specifies that the bag contains at least one instance of the target category. The caption y = − 1 specifies that the image does not contain any instance labels of the category. During the training, no instance labels are available. MIL problems are typically solved (locally) by finding a local minimum of a non-constant 2003 target function, such as the optimization of the SVL.

sections.heading: 4. Finding objects via submodular cover
sections.text: This year, we are in a position to put ourselves at the top.

sections.heading: 5. Iterative refinement with latent variables
sections.text: In this section, we discuss the latent SVM formulation and propose a simple smoothing technique that enables us to use classic techniques for unrestricted, smooth optimization. Figure 3 illustrates our analogy of multiple instance learning for object recognition with one-bit labels.

sections.heading: 5.1. Review of latent SVM
sections.text: For a binary classification problem, the latent SVM formulation consists of learning a decision function that includes a maximization level over a discrete set of configurations. (1) Given a data point x in Rp, which we want to classify, and some learned model parameters w in Rd, we select a label y in {-1, + 1} as follows: y = characters (max z).Z (7), where z is selected as a "latent variable" under the set Z, Z is typically a set of bouncing boxes, and maximized over Z, it boils down to finding a bouncing box containing the object (Felzenszwalb et al.), the set Z contains all possible sub-configurations that each part is associated with a position in the image. The resulting set Z is exponential in size, but (7) can be related to dynamic programming techniques for certain decisions.

sections.heading: 5.2. Smooth formulation of LSVM
sections.text: In the objective (8), the lingering loss in the maximizing (8) problem solving can easily be replaced by a smooth alternative, e.g. by a square arrangement (11) or a logistical loss. (9) We propose to use a smooth technique that can be examined by Nesterov (2005) for smooth functionality. (10) We only remember the simpler form of Nesterov's results that is relevant to our purpose. (9) Let us consider a non-smooth function that can be written in the following form: g (w).

sections.heading: 6. Experiments
sections.text: We conducted two experiments, one with a multiple learning dataset (Andrews et al., 2003) and the other with data from PASCAL VOC 2007 (Everingham et al.). The first experiment was designed to compare the multiple learning bag classification of LSVM with Smooth LSVM (SLSVM), and the second experiment evaluated the detection accuracy (measured with average precision) of our framework compared to baselines.

sections.heading: 6.1. Multiple instance learning datasets
sections.text: To allow a fair comparison with (Andrews et al., 2003), we use the same initialization, in which the initial weight vector is determined by training an SVM with all negative instances and bagged positive instances. For this experiment, we performed a 10-fold cross-validation on C and µ. Table 1 shows the experimental results. Without the bias, our method performs significantly better than the LSVM method, and with the bias, our method shows modest improvements in most cases.

sections.heading: 6.2. Weakly-supervised object detection
sections.text: This year it is so far that it will only take one year to move on to the next round.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: Our results show that the proposed framework can construct a number of positive windows to train initial detection models and improve models using the refinement optimization method. We achieve state-of-the-art object detection performance with minimal monitoring of the standard benchmark object detection data set. The source code will be available on the author's website.

Harchaoui were funded by the INRIA-UC Berkeley associated team "Hyperion," a grant from the France-Berkeley Fund, the Gargantua project under the Mastodons of CNRS program, and the LabEx PERSYVAL-Lab (ANR-11-LABX-0025), which was partially supported by ONR N00014-11-1-0688, NSF, DARPA, and Toyota.

Even though such a procedure does not have any theoretical guarantee about the quality of the optimization, it monotonically decreases the value of the objective and performs relatively well when the problem is well initialized (Felzenszwalb et al., 2010).
We propose to use a smoothing technique studied by Nesterov (2005) for convex functions.

As Nesterov (2005) shows, for a given target approximation accuracy , there is an optimal amount of smoothing μ( ) that can be derived from a convex optimization perspective using the strong convexity parameter of ω(·) on ∆ and the (usually unknown) Lipschitz constant of g.
Furthermore, smoothing latent SVM implicitly models uncertainty in the selection of the best configuration z in Z , as shown by Kumar et al. (2012) for a different smoothing scheme.

We use the recently proposed R-CNN (Girshick et al., 2014) detection framework to compute features on image windows in both cases.
Specifically, we use the convolutional neural network (CNN) distributed with DeCAF (Donahue et al., 2014), which is trained on the ImageNet ILSVRC 2012 dataset (using only image-level annotations).
We avoid using the better performing CNN that is fine-tuned on PASCAL data, as described in (Girshick et al., 2014), because fine-tuning requires instance-level annotations.

To evaluate the efficacy of our initialization, we compare it to the state-of-the-art algorithm recently proposed by (Siva et al., 2012).
For a fair comparison, we used the same window proposals, the same features (Girshick et al., 2014), the same L2 distance metric, and the same PASCAL 2007 detection evaluation criteria.
Figure 4 visualizes some command failure modes in our implementation of (Siva et al., 2012).

For a fair comparison, we used the same window proposals, the same features (Girshick et al., 2014), the same L2 distance metric, and the same PASCAL 2007 detection evaluation criteria. The class mean average precision for the mining algorithm was 11.6% compared to 29.0% obtained by our initialization procedure. Figure 4 visualizes some command failure modes in our implementation of (Siva et al., 2012). Since the negative mining method does not take into account the similarity among positive windows (in contrast to our method) our intuition is that the method is less robust to intra-class variations and background clutter. Therefore, it often latches onto background objects (i.e. hurdle in horse images, street signs in bus images), onto parts of the full objects (i.e. wheels of bicycles), or merges two different objects (i.e. rider and motorcycle). Therefore, it often latches onto background objects (i.e. hurdle in horse images, street signs in bus images), onto parts of the full objects (i.e. wheels of bicycles), or merges two different objects (i.e. rider and motorcycle). It is worth noting that Pandey & Lazebnik (2011); Siva et al. (2012) use the CorLoc metric1 as the evaluation metric to report results on PASCAL test set.
There are two baseline methods (Siva & Xiang, 2011; Russakovsky et al., 2012) which report the result on the full dataset.

metadata.abstractText: Learning to localize objects with minimal supervision is an important problem in computer vision, since large fully annotated datasets are extremely costly to obtain. In this paper, we propose a new method that achieves this goal with only image-level labels of whether the objects are present or not. Our approach combines a discriminative submodular cover problem for automatically discovering a set of positive object windows with a smoothed latent SVM formulation. The latter allows us to leverage efficient quasiNewton optimization techniques. Our experiments demonstrate that the proposed approach provides a 50% relative improvement in mean average precision over the current state-of-the-art on PASCAL VOC 2007 detection.
